main.subject-description: The Practical Informatics program at the University of Gdansk is a cutting-edge and comprehensive academic offering that bridges the gap between theoretical computer science and real-world applications. This program is designed to equip students with the knowledge, skills, and practical experience needed to excel in the dynamic field of informatics.
main.program-overview: Practical Informatics at the University of Gdansk is an interdisciplinary program that integrates computer science, mathematics, and practical problem-solving. It is tailored to prepare students for careers in various sectors, including software development, data analysis, information technology management, and more.
main.career-prospects: Graduates of the Practical Informatics program at the University of Gdansk are well-prepared for a variety of careers in both the public and private sectors. They can pursue roles as software developers, data analysts, IT consultants, cybersecurity specialists, database administrators, and more. The program's practical orientation ensures that graduates are job-ready and capable of meeting the evolving demands of the informatics industry.

subjects.subject: Elementary mathematics

skills.description: Analysis in elementary mathematics involves breaking down complex problems into simpler components. It encompasses the study of patterns, trends, and properties within numerical and algebraic structures.
Logic is the study of reasoning and the principles of valid argumentation. In elementary mathematics, it helps in constructing sound mathematical arguments and proofs.

Functions represent relationships between variables. In elementary mathematics, understanding functions involves recognizing input-output mappings and exploring how different mathematical operations affect these relationships.
Relations describe connections between sets of elements. In elementary mathematics, relations involve understanding how elements in one set relate to elements in another set.

subjects.subject description: Elementary mathematics is the foundational branch of mathematics that covers basic concepts such as numbers, arithmetic operations, algebra, geometry, and basic statistics. It provides the fundamental building blocks for more advanced mathematical studies and is essential for understanding and solving everyday quantitative problems.

subjects.subject: Discrete mathematics

skills.description: Graph theory studies the relationships and connections between discrete objects represented as vertices and edges. In discrete mathematics, it is used to model and analyze networks, relationships, and structures.
Probability in discrete mathematics deals with the likelihood of events occurring within a set of possible outcomes. It provides a mathematical framework for uncertainty and randomness.
Arithmetic in the context of discrete mathematics involves the study of whole numbers and their properties, including divisibility, prime numbers, and modular arithmetic.

subjects.subject description: Discrete mathematics focuses on mathematical structures and objects that are distinct and separated, rather than continuous. It includes topics such as graph theory, combinatorics, number theory, and logic. Discrete mathematics plays a vital role in computer science, cryptography, and various other fields where discrete structures and decision-making processes are essential.

subjects.subject: Programming workshop

skills.description: Git is a distributed version control system used for tracking changes in source code during software development. It enables collaboration among multiple developers by managing different versions of a project and facilitates branching, merging, and tracking changes over time.

Bash, or the Bourne Again Shell, is a command-line interpreter for Unix-like operating systems. It provides a text-based interface to interact with the system, execute commands, and automate tasks through scripting. Bash is a powerful tool for system administration and development workflows.

Linux is an open-source operating system kernel that serves as the foundation for various Unix-like operating systems. It is widely used in servers, embedded systems, and development environments. Understanding Linux is crucial for system administration, software development, and working with server-based applications.

The terminal, or command-line interface, is a text-based interface to interact with the computer's operating system. It provides a powerful way to execute commands, manage files, and perform various tasks without a graphical user interface. Terminals are commonly used in programming, system administration, and development workflows.

subjects.subject description: A Programming Workshop is an interactive learning session designed to impart practical skills and knowledge related to programming and software development. It typically involves hands-on activities, coding exercises, and collaborative projects to reinforce theoretical concepts. Workshops cater to participants with varying levels of programming experience, providing a supportive environment for skill development and problem-solving.

subjects.subject: Introduction to programming

skills.description: Participants are introduced to basic algorithms, step-by-step procedures for solving problems. Emphasis is on understanding algorithmic thinking and translating logical steps into executable code.
Core programming concepts are covered, including variables, control flow (if statements, loops), functions, and error handling. Participants learn to write structured and modular code.
The basics of data structures are explored, focusing on essential types such as lists, dictionaries, and sets. Participants understand how to organize and manipulate data efficiently.

subjects.subject description: An Introduction to Programming using Python is designed to provide beginners with a foundational understanding of key programming concepts, simple algorithms, and fundamental data structures. Python, known for its readability and versatility, serves as an accessible language for newcomers to the world of coding.

subjects.subject: Computer Networks

skills.description: Participants delve into the basics of computer networks, learning about different types of networks (Local Area Networks - LANs, Wide Area Networks - WANs), network devices, and the principles of data transmission across networks.

Understanding network protocols is essential. Participants explore the rules and conventions that govern data communication, including the TCP/IP suite. Protocols such as HTTP, FTP, and SMTP are discussed, emphasizing their roles in enabling different network services.

The architecture of the internet is explored, covering the interconnected web of networks globally. Topics include the client-server model, the Domain Name System (DNS), and the role of Internet Service Providers (ISPs) in facilitating connectivity.

Routing and switching form the backbone of network functionality. Participants learn about routers and switches, the mechanisms behind data packet forwarding, and the protocols (e.g., RIP, OSPF) that determine optimal paths for data to travel through a network.

subjects.subject description: The study of Computer Networks encompasses various aspects, including fundamental network concepts, communication protocols, internet architecture, and the critical processes of routing and switching.

subjects.subject: Web introduction

skills.description: HTML serves as the backbone of web content. Participants learn the structure of web pages, understanding how to create and organize content using HTML elements. Topics include headings, paragraphs, links, lists, and basic forms.

CSS is introduced for styling and layout purposes. Participants explore the styling of HTML elements, including text formatting, color schemes, layout models, and responsive design principles. The concept of selectors and specificity is emphasized.

Building on CSS, participants are introduced to SASS, a preprocessor scripting language. SASS enhances the capabilities of CSS by introducing variables, nesting, mixins, and other features that streamline the styling process.

subjects.subject description: A Web Introduction course provides foundational knowledge for individuals interested in web development. It covers essential technologies such as HTML (Hypertext Markup Language), CSS (Cascading Style Sheets), and introduces more advanced styling with SASS (Syntactically Awesome Stylesheets)

subjects.subject: Databases 1

skills.description: Participants learn the principles of designing efficient and normalized databases. Topics include entity-relationship modeling, defining tables, establishing relationships, and ensuring data integrity through normalization.

The course covers the basics of database administration, including installation, configuration, and management of database systems. Participants gain insights into security measures, backup and recovery procedures, and performance optimization.

Data modeling is introduced as a crucial step in the database design process. Participants explore conceptual, logical, and physical data modeling, emphasizing the importance of accurately representing real-world scenarios within the database structure.

T-SQL, the extension of SQL for Microsoft SQL Server, is introduced for querying and manipulating data. Participants learn the syntax for creating and managing database objects, writing queries, and performing common data manipulation tasks.

subjects.subject description: Databases 1 is an introductory course that provides a comprehensive understanding of fundamental database concepts, encompassing database design, administration, data modeling, and T-SQL (Transact-SQL).

subjects.subject: English

skills.description: Participants learn and practice the specific technical vocabulary used in informatics, including terms related to programming languages, algorithms, data structures, and system architecture.

The course emphasizes effective communication strategies in both written and verbal forms. Participants learn to convey complex technical concepts clearly and concisely, fostering efficient collaboration within the informatics community.

Writing skills are honed with a focus on various genres relevant to informatics, such as technical documentation, research papers, and project reports. Participants develop the ability to articulate ideas logically and persuasively.

The course addresses the nuances of professional communication within the informatics context. This includes email etiquette, presentation skills, and effective communication in meetings and discussions.

subjects.subject description: Participants exit the course with enhanced English language skills specifically tailored for the informatics domain, enabling them to communicate effectively in professional settings, write technical documents with clarity, and navigate various communication challenges within the field of informatics.

subjects.subject: Mathematical fundamental of informatics

skills.description: Regular expressions are a powerful tool for pattern matching and text processing. They are a concise way to describe sets of strings based on specific patterns.
Turing machines and automata are abstract mathematical models of computation. They consist of states, transitions, and an input tape and help analyze the capabilities and limitations of algorithms.

Are used to describe context-free languages. A context-free grammar is a set of recursive rules used to generate patterns of strings. A context-free grammar can describe all regular languages and more, but they cannot describe all possible languages.

subjects.subject description: These mathematical concepts form the backbone of theoretical computer science and informatics. They provide a formal and abstract framework for understanding and analyzing computational processes, algorithms, and the structure of information. A solid grasp of these fundamentals is essential for anyone involved in computer science, software development, and related fields.

subjects.subject: Linear Algebra

skills.description: Participants learn the basic operations involving matrices, including addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication, and matrix multiplication. These operations lay the foundation for more advanced linear algebra concepts.

The course addresses the representation and solution of systems of linear equations. Participants learn techniques such as Gaussian elimination and matrix inverses to solve systems of equations and analyze the properties of solutions.

The dot product (also known as the inner product) is introduced as a fundamental operation in linear algebra. Participants explore its geometric interpretation, properties, and applications in vector spaces.

Matrix-vector multiplication is covered, emphasizing its role in transforming vectors and solving systems of linear equations. Participants learn to represent linear transformations using matrices and understand their impact on vector spaces.

subjects.subject description: Linear Algebra is a mathematical discipline that explores vector spaces and linear mappings between these spaces. The course covers fundamental concepts such as operations on matrices, systems of linear equations, the dot product, and matrix-vector multiplication.

subjects.subject: Algorithms and data structures

skills.description: Participants study specific sorting algorithms, including Heapsort and Quicksort. Emphasis is placed on understanding their principles, implementation, and analyzing their efficiency in different scenarios.

The course delves into the analysis of algorithmic efficiency, considering semantic correctness, pessimistic time complexity, and lower bounds of pessimistic and expected time complexity. Participants explore mathematical models for evaluating algorithm performance.
The course covers essential data structures, including stacks, queues, and linked structures. Participants learn how to implement and utilize these structures to efficiently manage and organize data.

subjects.subject description: The course on Algorithms and Data Structures provides an in-depth understanding of fundamental algorithms, various data structures, and techniques for analyzing their time complexity.

subjects.subject: Programing laguages 1

skills.description: Participants explore asynchronous programming, understanding the principles behind concurrent execution, non-blocking operations, and event-driven architectures. Concepts such as callbacks, promises, and async/await patterns are covered.

Scala, a versatile programming language, is introduced. Participants learn the language syntax, its object-oriented and functional features, and how to leverage Scala for building scalable and concise code.

The course delves into the principles of object-oriented programming (OOP) and functional programming (FP). Participants understand how to combine these paradigms for effective code design and readability.

The course covers the collection mechanisms available in the chosen programming language(s), emphasizing data structures like lists, maps, and sets. Participants learn to manipulate and process collections using both imperative and functional styles.

subjects.subject description: The Programming Languages 1 course provides an introduction to advanced programming concepts, including asynchronous programming, Scala programming language, and a blend of object-oriented and functional programming paradigms, with a focus on collection mechanisms.

subjects.subject: Programing laguages 2

skills.description: Participants deepen their understanding of JavaScript, a versatile and widely used programming language. The course covers advanced language features, functional programming concepts, and best practices for writing clean and maintainable code.

Node.js is introduced as a server-side runtime for JavaScript. Participants learn how to build scalable and high-performance applications using Node.js, including setting up servers, handling HTTP requests, and leveraging the event-driven architecture.

The course explores asynchronous programming patterns in JavaScript, including the event loop, callbacks, promises, and async/await. Participants gain a deep understanding of managing asynchronous operations in both client-side and server-side code.

Yarn, a package manager for JavaScript, is introduced for managing project dependencies efficiently. Participants learn how to use Yarn to install, manage, and update packages in their JavaScript projects.

subjects.subject description: Programming Languages 2 is a continuation of language exploration, focusing on JavaScript and Node.js. The course covers asynchronous programming in the context of JavaScript, and the use of Yarn as a package manager.

subjects.subject: Contemporary applications of computer science

skills.description: The course features discussions and lectures led by industry professionals and experts. Participants engage with practitioners who share insights, experiences, and real-world applications of computer science in diverse industries.

Participants explore recent innovations and emerging technologies in the field of computer science. This may include discussions on artificial intelligence, machine learning, blockchain, quantum computing, and other contemporary areas.

The course delves into the diverse applications of computer science across industries such as healthcare, finance, entertainment, transportation, and more. Participants gain an understanding of how computer science is driving innovation and transforming different sectors.

subjects.subject description: The course on Contemporary Applications of Computer Science provides an overview of the latest developments, innovations, and applications within the field. It includes discussions and lectures with industry professionals, exploration of cutting-edge technologies, and an examination of various areas where computer science is making a significant impact.

subjects.subject: Social and legal aspects of IT

skills.description: Participants study the legal principles surrounding copyright protection for digital content. This includes understanding the scope of protection, fair use, licensing, and the challenges posed by digital reproduction and distribution.

The course delves into the legal recognition and use of electronic signatures. Participants learn about the legal frameworks and standards governing the validity and enforceability of electronic signatures in various jurisdictions.

Participants explore the legal landscape of electronic transactions, including contracts and agreements conducted in the digital realm. Topics include the legal validity of online contracts, electronic records, and dispute resolution.

The course covers the legal aspects of computer-related criminal activities. This includes offenses such as hacking, identity theft, cyber fraud, and the legal frameworks for investigating and prosecuting computer crimes.

subjects.subject description: The course on Social and Legal Aspects of IT explores the intersection between information technology and the legal and social frameworks that govern its use. It covers topics such as copyright protection, electronic signatures, legal transactions in the electronic realm, and the legal aspects of computer-related criminal activities.

subjects.subject: English

skills.description: Participants learn and practice the specific technical vocabulary used in informatics, including terms related to programming languages, algorithms, data structures, and system architecture.

The course emphasizes effective communication strategies in both written and verbal forms. Participants learn to convey complex technical concepts clearly and concisely, fostering efficient collaboration within the informatics community.

Writing skills are honed with a focus on various genres relevant to informatics, such as technical documentation, research papers, and project reports. Participants develop the ability to articulate ideas logically and persuasively.

The course addresses the nuances of professional communication within the informatics context. This includes email etiquette, presentation skills, and effective communication in meetings and discussions.
